page.title: 01Cricklade,9thC Saxon Borough
page.content: Cricklade is a good example of 9th c Saxon 'New town' boroughs on upper reaches of Thames. The layout is largely unchanged. The town centre buildings date from 18th and 19th century and is dominated by fine 16th c Tower of St Sampsonschurch. Outlying modern housing estates are homes of a dormitory population which has doubled since World War II. About 80% of land in this block is under agriculture. But weekly markets have not been held since 1936. The ancient Common called North Meadow is still common and forms a part of an extensive floodplain to north of town through which the rivers Thames and Church flow. From early in 1st century until 1975 all traffic along the Roman Ermin Street passed through Cricklade and along the causeway,but such traffic is now diverted along a bypass
